title: Protocol for the use of signal amplification by exchange reaction-fluorescence in situ hybridization on adult formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded mouse lung tissue
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Design probes (Day - 5–7)
Timing: hands on time - 2–3 h
        Obtain reference sequence for gene of interest from NCBI (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2746-Fig1.jpg
              Figure 1. Export FASTA file for gene of interest from NCBI
            
(A) Mus musculus Fgf10 transcript was identified from NCBI.
              (B) Mus musculus Fgf10 mRNA FASTA file was downloaded from NCBI to
              be uploaded into OligoMinerApp.
            
        Type your gene of interest into the search bar for NCBI. For example,
        FGF10. And open the gene result.
      
Change the ortholog to “mouse.”
        Scroll down to the “NCBI Reference Sequences” and select the mRNA
        sequence. For FGF10, select NP_008002.5.
      
        Click “send to” and select “coding sequences” (for exons only) or
        “complete record” (for the full gene) and download the "FASTA
        nucleotide” for the coding sequence or click file and download the FASTA
        formatted sequence for complete record (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
      
Note: The untranslated regions can be
      included if the gene of interest has a less than 20 probes within the exon
      regions.
    
Note: Introns can also be included to
      analyze splicing.
    
        Open OligoMinerApp (http://oligominerapp.org/[href=http://oligominerapp.org/])3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3] and select “Input-Single” to input a single
        FASTA-formatted sequence by uploading the file generated from NCBI.
      
        Adjust the settings so that the bp limit is 25–50, formamide
        concentration is 40%, the NN table is RNA_NN, reference sequence is Mus
        musculus, and output strand should be the minus(-) strand (reverse
        complement of the mRNA target) (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]). The rest
        of the settings can remain as default.
      
Submit the form and export the resulting probes.
        Add a linker sequence (TTT) followed by a 9nt primer sequence to each
        probe. All probes for one RNA target will need the same 9nt primer
        sequence. (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2746-Fig2.jpg
              Figure 2. SABER-FISH probe, branch, and hairpin design

(A) Probes contain a “TTT” and a 9nt primer sequence.
              (B) hairpins are designed to add 10nt after each round of
              amplification in PER.
            
              (C) Branches (after they are extended) bind to the extended
              probes.
            
              (D) Fluorescent probes are designed to bind to the last branch
              added to the tissue.
            
Note: >(probe) TTT (9nt primer). For
      example, >(FGF10 probe) TTT (GGG CCC GGG).
    
Note: we recommend using different 9nt
      primer sequences for each different RNA target for multiplexing.
    
        Design the hairpin for extending the 9nt primer on the probe (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
      
Note: >A (9nt primer sequence)
      GGGCCTTTGGCCC (reverse complement of 9nt primer sequence) T (reverse
      complement of 9nt primer sequence) TTTTTTT. For example, >A (GGG CCC
      GGG) GGGCCTTTGGCCC (CCC GGG CCC) T (CCC GGG CCC) TTTTTTT.
    
        Design1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1],2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2],3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3],4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4] branches for
        signal amplification (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
      
Note: >(reverse complement of 9nt
      primer sequence) T (reverse complement of 9nt primer sequence) T (reverse
      complement of 9nt primer sequence) TTT (9nt NEW primer sequence). For
      example, > (CCC GGG CCC) T (CCC GGG CCC) T (CCC GGG CCC) TTT (ATA TAT
      ATA).
    
Note: each branch will also require a
      hairpin for extension (see step 7) and it is designed the same way as for
      probes. (Repeat steps 8 and 7 for additional branches).
    
Design fluorescent probes (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D).
Note: >/5dye/ TT (reverse complement of
      primer sequence of last branch added to amplify the signal) T (reverse
      complement of primer sequence of last branch added to amplify the signal)
      ) T. For example, >/5ATTO565/ TT (TAT ATA TAT) T (TAT ATA TAT).
    
Note: fluorescent probes should be
      designed for the primers on the last branch added to amplify the signal.
    
Note: fluorescent dye choice depends on
      your specific microscopic needs and whether you plan on multiplexing
      several probes.
    
Prepare reagents (Day - 5–7)
Timing: 2 h

Reagents for the protocol can be prepared ahead of time.
        Order the probes, hairpins, branches, and Clean G from Integrated DNA
        Technologies (IDT) with standard desalting. Order fluorescent probes
        from IDT with HPLC purification.
      
Note: These items can be ordered in
      96-well plate form to save costs.
    
Note: C bases are used as stop sequences
      because there are no G bases in the reaction mix and the polymerase will
      stall. Clean G is necessary to remove any contaminating G nucleotides in
      the reaction mix. Clean G sequence:
      CCCCGAAAGTGGCCTCGGGCCTTTTGGCCCGAGGCCACTTTCG.
    
        Resuspend the probes at 100 μM (either in plate or tube form) with
        nuclease free water.
      
        Allow the probes to dissolve into the nuclease free water for 10 min at
        room temperature (20°C–25°C).
      
        Mix the probes (from a single RNA target) with equal amounts of each
        probe.
      
        Create 18mM solutions of dATP, dTTP, and dCTP. (18 μL 100mM dNTP in
        82 μL of nuclease free water).
      
        Combine equal amounts of diluted (18mM) dATP, dTTP, and dCTP so each is
        6mM.
      
Prepare buffers.
Note: Buffers are prepared per sample
      based on our adaptation using a 10x Visium cassette. We recommend 2x-3x as
      much if using traditional FISH hybridization chambers.
    
Note: Buffers should be prepared without
      the probes. The probes should be maintained at −20°C until just before
      using.
    
Sectioning tissue (Day - 1)
Timing: 16 h
      Adult mouse lung FFPE tissues are sectioned (5–7μm) onto + charged slides.
    
Critical: Perform all steps under
      RNase free conditions.
    
        Wipe microtome, water bath, and tools for sectioning with RNase-Zap
        wipes. Load microtome with a fresh cutting blade.
      
        Put fresh RNase/DNase-free water in the waterbath. Set water bath
        temperature to 42°C and allow it to reach temperature.
      
        If using 10x Visium cassette, outline wells on the back of slides (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2746-Fig3.jpg

Figure 3. Prepare slide for SABER-FISH
            
              (A) The wells on the 10X Visium cassette were outlined on the back
              of a + charged slide.
            
              (B) A FFPE lung tissue was placed onto the slide such that the
              tissue was within the well outline.
            
        Section and discard the first 2–3 5um sections from the first tissue
        block.
      
Critical: the first 2–3 sections can
      have degraded RNA or RNases and are thus, not desirable for FISH.
    
        Move the blade to a fresh area and cut 5um sections for FISH. Place the
        section in waterbath and allow it to melt slightly.
      
Critical: Because the first few
      sections could contain RNases, it is necessary to cut sections on a new
      part of the blade.
    
        After the wrinkles have been smoothed, place the section on the slide
        (in the topmost square if using 10x Visium cassette; (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B)).
      
        Repeat for each tissue block. Each section should be placed into a
        separate square.
      
        Place finished slides in a 37°C humidified slide dryer for 16–24 h.
      
      Primer exchange reaction (PER) (Day - 1)4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]
Timing: 12 h
Probes and branches are extended and prepared for hybridization.
        Prepare a thermal cycler program with the following program and begin
        the program.
      
table:files/protocols_protocol_2746_10.csv
        Mix the reagents for probe PER and branch PER in PCR tubes on ice. Each
        probe and branch require separate tubes.
      
table:files/protocols_protocol_2746_11.csv
table:files/protocols_protocol_2746_12.csv
Place PCR tube in the thermal cycler and skip the “37°C forever.”
        After 15 min, add 5 μL of the probe mix or 10 μL of the branch to the
        appropriate PCR tube.
      
Allow the program to finish.
Image and purify PER (Day 0)
Timing: 1 h
Probe and branch extensions are verified and purified.
        Make a 1.25% agarose gel and add 1 μL of SYBR Gold per 10mL of agarose.

Note: We do not recommend using Ethidium
      bromide as it does not detect single stranded DNA easily. SYBR Gold has
      worked well for us but any DNA dye that detects single stranded DNA will
      work.
    
        After the gel solidifies, add DNA ladder, probe pool/branch pool
        (5–10 μL with 1–2 μL of 6x loading buffer, respectively), and each PER
        (10 μL with 2 μL of 6x loading buffer).
      
Run the gel at 150V for 15 min.
Image the gel.
Run the gel again at 150V for 15 more min.
Image the gel.
        The PER should have extended to 500–1000bp in length to make for an
        efficient and useful probe/branch (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]). The
        PER can be stored at −20°C for up to 6 months. Avoid repeated
        freeze/thaw cycles.
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2746-Fig4.jpg
              Figure 4. PER extension of a branch sequence
            
              A 100bp ladder compared to unextended branch (10 μL) and a PER
              extended branch at around 500bp.
            
        Purify 5 μg of PER with
        Qiagen MinElute PCR Purification Kit[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=8f6b09b2-6dcd-4b55-bb4a-255ede40ca3b&lang=en]
        according to the manufacturer’s protocol.
      
Note: More than 5 μg of PER can be
      purified at once if more than 10 μL of purified PER are needed for
      hybridization.
    
        Keep purified PER at −20°C until ready for use. The purified PER can be
        stored at −20°C for up to 6 months. Avoid repeated freeze/thaw cycles.
      
Deparaffinization and rehydration (Day 0)
Timing: 3 h
Samples are prepared for hybridization.
Note: Prewarm a dry 60°C oven (or thermal
      cycler if using 10x Visium cassette).
    
Critical: Perform all steps under
      RNase free conditions.
    
        Remove slide(s) from 37°C humidified slide drying and place at 60°C for
        2 h.
      
        Allow the slide to cool to RT and deparaffinize by immersing slide in
        toluene (xylene), such that the tissues are covered, twice each for

10 min. Replace toluene between each 10-min incubation (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2746-Fig5.jpg
              Figure 5. Deparaffinization and rehydration of tissues for
              SABER-FISH
            
              (A) Slides are immersed in toluene for 10 min. Tissues need to be
              covered with toluene.
            
              (B) Slides are then immersed in decreasing concentrations of
              ethanol in water (30mL is sufficient to cover tissues in a 50mL
              conical tube).
            
              (C and D) The slide is placed on the 10X Visium thermal cycler
              adapter without closing the lid.
            
Critical: Use RNase-free Coplin jar.
    
Prepare thermal cycler to 37°C with Visium slide adapter.
        Incubate slide in 100% ethanol twice for 3 min. Replace ethanol between
        each 3-min incubation (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B).
      
Note: Use 50mL conical tubes for the
      ethanol incubation steps. 30mL of liquid in a 50mL conical tube is
      sufficient to cover the tissues.
    
        Incubate slide on thermal cycler Visium adapter for 15 min at 37°C. Do
        not close the lid (Figures 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]C and 5D).
      
Incubate slide in 100% ethanol for 3 min.
Incubate slide in 96% ethanol twice for 3 min.
Incubate slide in 70% ethanol for 3 min.
Incubate slide in RNase/DNase-free water for 20 s.
Let the slide air dry.
Decrosslinking and hybridization (Day 0)
Timing: 18 h
Samples are prepared for hybridization.
        Place the slide on the thermal cycler Visium adapter for 3 min at 37°C.
      
Remove the slide and set the thermal cycler and lid to 70°C.
        Insert the slide into the 10x Visium cassette without disturbing the
        tissues (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2746-Fig6.jpg
              Figure 6. Use of the 10X Visium slide cassette
            
              (A) Gently place the slide into the cassette so the tissue is not
              disturbed.
            
              (B) Add liquid to cassette along the sides of the wells as to not
              disturb the tissue.
            
              (C) Seal the top of the wells on the cassette during incubations

so the liquid does not evaporate.
            
        Add 150 μL 1x TE buffer (pH 9.0) along the side of the cassette wells.
      
Critical: Do not add any buffer
      directly on the tissue samples as it can disrupt the tissues (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B).
    
        Remove all TE buffer from the wells. Careful not to disturb the tissues.
      
Add 100 μL TE buffer (pH 9.0) along the side of the wells.
        Seal the Visium cassette with a seal to prevent evaporation (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]C).
      
Note: Plate seals for 96-well or 384-well
      plates can be used, just cut the seals to the size of the cassette.
    
Incubate the slide at 70°C for 1 h with the lid closed.
Remove the cassette and place on a flat, clean surface.
Remove the seal on the cassette.
        Remove all the TE buffer from the wells and add 100 μL 1x PBS for 5 min
        at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
      
Remove the PBS from the wells and 100 μL pre-hybridization mix.
Incubate at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 15 min.
        Remove all the pre-hybridization mix from the wells and add Primary
        probe mix to the wells.
      
        Incubate at 43°C for 16 h.
        
Note: temperature may vary depending
          on the melting temperature of the probes and the concentration of
          formamide.
        
First branch (Day 1)
Timing: 11.5 h (timing may vary
      depending on optimization of branches)
    
      Primary branches are added to the sample after primary probe
      hybridization.
    
        Remove the slides from the thermal cycler and set the thermal cycler to
        37°C.
      
        Remove the seal and remove all the Primary probe mix and quickly replace
        it with prewarmed (37°C) Wash buffer.
      
        Remove the Wash buffer and then wash twice for 30 min at 37°C with Wash
        buffer.
      
Wash the samples twice with 2x SSC for 5 min each at 37°C.

Add the first branch mix to the slide, cover with a seal, and
        incubate at 37°C for 10 h.
      
Second branch (Day 1)
Timing: 11.5 h (timing may vary
      depending on optimization of branches)
    
      Secondary branches are added to the sample after primary branch
      hybridization.
    
        Remove the seal and remove all the first branch mix and quickly replace
        it with prewarmed (37°C) Wash buffer.
      
        Remove the Wash buffer and then wash twice for 30 min at 37°C with Wash
        buffer.
      
Wash the samples twice with 2x SSC for 5 min each at 37°C.
        Add the second branch mix to the slide, cover with a seal, and
        incubate at 37°C for 10 h.
      
Repeat for branch 3–4, if necessary.
Fluorescent probes (Day 2)
Timing: 3–4 h (timing may vary depending
      on optimization of fluorescent probes)
    
Fluorescent probes are added to the sample for visualization of RNA.
        Remove the seal and remove all the second branch mix and quickly replace
        it with prewarmed (37°C) Wash buffer.
      
        Remove the Wash buffer and then wash twice for 30 min at 37°C with Wash
        buffer.
      
Wash the samples twice with 2x SSC for 5 min each at 37°C.
        Wash the samples twice with Antibody wash buffer for 5 min each at 37°C.
      
        Add the fluorescent probe mix to the slide, cover with a seal, and
        incubate at 37°C for 1.5 h.
      
Note: Slides need to be kept in the dark
      until the end of the protocol to preserve the fluorescent signal.
    
        Remove the seal and remove all the fluorescent probe mix and wash slides
        twice with 0.1% Tween-20 in PBS for 5 min each.
      
Remove the slides from the cassette.
Critical: Be careful in removing the
      slide from the cassette as to not disrupt the tissue.

Slides can be imaged first to check for FISH signal or can proceed to
        immunostaining (step 68).
      
        If the slides are imaged: mount with mounting media and coverslip and
        place on microscope of choice.
      
Note: To get good resolution of each RNA
      spot, we recommend confocal or super-resolution microscopes with a 20x
      objective and imaging in a format that results in a pixel size of
      160 nm × 160 nm).
    
        To remove coverslip, incubate the slide in PBS and allow for the
        coverslip to naturally fall off the slide.
      
Critical: Do not force the coverslip
      off the slide as this will disrupt the tissue.
    
Immunostaining – primary (Day 2)
Timing: 45 min
      Antibody staining is performed for colocalization of RNA target and cells.
    
Circle the tissue with a PAP pen.
Critical: Do not let the sections dry
      out. If needed, a small amount of blocking buffer can be added on the
      sections while circling with the PAP pen.
    
        Incubate with 50 μL blocking buffer per sample for a minimum of 30 min
        at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
      
        During this time, dilute primary antibodies in staining buffer. Be sure
        to keep diluted antibodies in staining buffer on ice.
      
        After blocking, tap the buffer off and replace with 50 μL primary
        antibody solution.
      
Incubate with antibodies for 16–24 h at 4°C.
Note: Concentrations of primary antibodies
      will differ and will need to be determined by each user.
    
Note: Antibodies will need to be tested to
      determine if they work with TE buffer decrosslinking.
    
Immunostaining – secondary and imaging (Day 3)
Timing: 3.5–4 h
Secondary antibodies are added for visualization via microscopy.
Remove slides from 4°C and tap off the primary antibody solution.
        Wash the sample 3 times with 50 μL of Antibody wash solution for 5 min
        each.

During this time, dilute fluorescent secondary antibodies in staining
        buffer.
      
Note: Choose fluorescent secondary
      antibodies that will not overlap with fluorescent probe.
    
        Tap off the last wash and replace with fluorescent antibody solution.
        Incubate for 3 h at at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
      
        Wash the sample 3 times with 50 μL of Antibody wash solution for 5 min
        each.
      
        Tap off the last wash and mount the slide with mounting media and a
        coverslip.
      
        Proceed immediately to imaging. Slides can be stored after mounting for
        2 weeks at 4°C.
